that both will occur is the product of the individual probabili-
ties—if you toss a fair die twice, then the chance of getting two sixes is 1 in
36; for, on each toss, the probability is 1 in 6, and, since the tosses are inde-
pendent of one another, you multiply. The other idea is that, when you have
a range of alternatives and don’t have any reasons for thinking that one is
more  likely  to  occur  than  another,  each  of  the  possibilities  has  an  equal
